trans-unit.source: 1.2.0 adds 4D simplex noise, tiling for 2D simplex noise, and parameterized lacunarity
trans-unit.target: 1.2.0では、4次元単軸ノイズ、2次元単軸ノイズのタイリング、パラメータ化されたラクラリティが追加されました。

trans-unit.source: 1.2.1 Fixes MSVC compatibility (Thanks to Christoph Gohlke)
trans-unit.target: 1.2.1 MSVC互換性の修正(Christoph Gohlke氏に感謝します。

trans-unit.source: 1.2.2 AppVeyor support for Windows builds (Thanks to Federico Tomassetti)
trans-unit.target: 1.2.2 AppVeyor の Windows ビルドへの対応 (Federico Tomassetti 氏に感謝します)

trans-unit.source: Perlin noise is ubiquitous in modern CGI. Used for procedural texturing, animation, and enhancing realism, Perlin noise has been called the “salt” of procedural content. Perlin noise is a type of gradient noise, smoothly interpolating across a pseudo-random matrix of values.
trans-unit.target: Perlin noise is ubiquitous in modern CGI. Used for procedural texturing, animation, and enhancing realism, Perlin noise has been called the “salt” of procedural content. Perlin noise is a type of gradient noise, smoothly interpolating across a pseudo-random matrix of values.
詳細はCHANGES.txtを参照してください。

trans-unit.source: The Perlin improved noise functions can also generate fBm (fractal Brownian motion) noise by combining multiple octaves of Perlin noise. Shader functions for convenient generation of turbulent noise are also included.
trans-unit.target: また、Perlin改良ノイズ関数は、複数オクターブのPerlinノイズを組み合わせてfBm(フラクタルブラウン運動)ノイズを生成することができます。乱流ノイズの生成に便利なシェーダ機能も搭載しています。

trans-unit.source: The noise library includes native-code implementations of Perlin “improved” noise and Perlin simplex noise. It also includes a fast implementation of Perlin noise in GLSL, for use in OpenGL shaders. The shader code and many of the included examples require Pyglet (http://www.pyglet.org), the native-code noise functions themselves do not, however.
trans-unit.target: The noise library includes native-code implementations of Perlin “improved” noise and Perlin simplex noise. It also includes a fast implementation of Perlin noise in GLSL, for use in OpenGL shaders. The shader code and many of the included examples require Pyglet (http://www.pyglet.org), the native-code noise functions themselves do not, however.
